title: Will pro-democracy candidates win a Legislative Council majority in Hong Kong's next legislative election?
possible_answers: No election will be held in 2020
correct_answer: No election will be held in 2020
preds: I am conflicted on how to answer this "properly" as the CCP may have an "election." The problem is will it be enough of an "election" for this question to consider it an "election?"
With the level of unrest still high. China will hold off on elections.
The election has been postponed to 2021. Which will halt any pro-democracy momentum and slow HK protests. Main land china will seek to undermined pro-democracy momentum and elect pro-china members.

Government has already announced postponement of elections to 2021. I do not believe the government will not go back on its word on this one.

Confirmed by BBC that this election has been postponed for a year.  Asking for resolution. Source: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-53563090
Hong Kong announced postponement. of Elections for one year, blaming the Corona virus as opposed to a political move. This has been disputed by opposition reps.
Hong Kong’s embattled leader has invoked emergency powers to postpone the Legislative Council elections scheduled for September by one year, citing health risks from the resurgent Covid-19 crisis.

They were very sad to do this, but on the bright side they have noticed that this gives them plenty of time to round up the Usual Suspects. And their families.  And their friends.  Pretty heartwarming, I'd say.

Postponement being announced now by Carrie Lam. No time given for this postponement, yet the rumour (by Sky News and my previous forecast's article) is up to one year, likely a year, so slightly hedging against this as could be within the timeframe.

12 of the pro-democracy candidates were recently disqualified from this election, with the possibility of more disqualifications. A second coronavirus wave is hitting Hong Kong, so it's possible the election will be postponed, but I doubt it. Now that the pro-democracy candidates are mostly out, it seems like Beijing would pressure Lam to go ahead with the election.
My forecast has just been pegged with the disqualification of candidates. Next question please.
There will be a lovely election, greatly simplified by the disqualification, incarceration, or disappearance of anybody who might win.
Adjusting chance of election postponement to 2% as I really don’t believe it.

12 pro democracy candidates are banned from running. This tells me that the election is rigged in favor of the pro-China camp. I still give a 15% chance that a hugely overwhelming turnout gives the majority to the pro democracy camp.
Now, will the elections be postponed to after 2020? It seems that Hong Kong has a traditionally consistent 4-year term between elections, so I will only assign a 5% to postponement due to unrest.
12 more pro dem candidates have been barred from running

If more than 1-2 week passes without movement, then I'll adjust more towards my initial forecast. It seems pretty clear that if Beijing wants to continue their power grab in Hong Kong that they will postpone the election, and then install candidates of their choice for next year's vote. And Beijing isn't shy about any of this.

The general consensus in the media is that there is significant if not a majority for Pro Democracy but China is quite hardline at the moment. It’s seems likely any election will only occur if Pro democracy lose.
China will manipulate the elections, e.g., by declaring key candidates ineligible, or it will can the election outright.

Article 159(4) prevents members of the legislature from establishing laws that interfere with the basic relationship which makes HK a special administrative region of China.  Article 104 sets forth a code of allegiance by members to the Special Administrative Region. The nomination form and confirmation form ensure candidates retain and plan on perpetuating these ideals.  In 2016 they were tested. Burgeoning dissension for China boiled for the first time in 2016 when 6 candidates, a mix of localist and pro-independents, were rejected for either not signing their loyalty to Basic law  through the nomination form, or the follow up confirmation form. Leung was rejected by EAC officer Cora Ho Lai-Sheung AFTER he signed the nomination form.  She attached clippings of facebook posts and other proof that his interest was ultimately a subversive push for HK independence. Most if not all of the current localist candidates are outspoken HK secession advocates, and assuming the hurdled nomination form is surpassed, it is clear that Edward Leung set a standard for behavior. The new candidates most likely have already stamped and recorded their opinion of the matter in blogs or posts readily retrievable by HK and Chinese authorities, who will unilaterally extinguish hopes of a 36-35 legislature. The National Security Law buttresses and reinforces the relationship between China and Hong Kong, minimizing the risk of a pro-democracy uprising.  please refer to the astute @benjuliano1 for an additional and expanded opinion
@ManuPV this is definitely in your wheelhouse

Full credit to @Orao for some eagle-eyed research that led to this update. It really pains me to make this update because I can’t imagine the fear and anger the people of Hong Kong must be experiencing right now. Sadly, I can only predict the future of geopolitics, not change it. On Thursday, the Electoral Affairs Commission (EAC), a puppet of the Communist Party announced that all candidates running for the Legislative Council would have to sign a declaration stating that they will ‘uphold the Basic Law and pledge allegiance to the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region’. A thinly veiled pledge of allegiance to the Chinese State which virtually bans anyone associated with the pro-democracy movement from standing in elections.  Just in case any candidates decided to sign the form and then renege on it after a successful campaign, the EAC affirmed ‘that returning officers have the power to determine whether the declaration made by a person seeking candidature in the nomination form that they will uphold the Basic Law and pledge allegiance to the Hong Kong SAR is genuine, to decide whether the nomination is valid.’ effectively allowing officials to retroactively bar pro-democracy candidates from taking their seats on the Legislative Council. [1] The Party realized they were in danger of completely losing control of the primary stage and decided they would preempt any early celebrations by the pro-democracy movement. On Monday, Chinese state news agency Xin Hua accused voters in the widely anticipated primary of ‘disregard[ing] the lives and safety of citizens to gather crowds for political gain multiple times, and creat[ing] the biggest loophole in the anti-epidemic efforts’ after an estimated 610,000 Hong Kongers lined the streets vote. [2] An editorial in the Hong Kong Free Press appeared to accept defeat in the election before a single vote had even been cast. ‘[I]f we cannot immediately “liberate” the city, we can at least make the Chinese Communist Party pay the highest possible price for breaching an international treaty, breaking its promises and destroying Hong Kong’s autonomy and freedoms,' Benedict Rogers, founder of Hong Kong Watch, wrote. [3] The question should now really read: ‘Will pro-democracy candidates win a Legislative Council majority in Hong Kong's rigged legislative election?’. The answer: Absolutely not. [1]https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2020/07/20200716/20200716_170845_022.html
[2]https://hongkongfp.com/2020/07/20/state-media-blames-hong-kong-democrat-primaries-for-covid-19-surge-as-medics-question-govts-growing-quarantine-exemption-list/
[3]https://hongkongfp.com/2020/07/18/a-tale-of-two-cities-the-one-beijing-wants-and-the-one-hongkongers-are-fighting-for/

China is feeling pressure from western economies and will continue to be economically isolated. Therefore an election will be held. Because China will certainly never allow outside influence in elections, those pro-democracy candidates will be “touted” as outside influences and declared unfit to run in the elections. There is a very small chance that China is engaged in an internal conflict allowing pro-democracy candidates to run and win a majority.
1 word - China.  (Unfortunately, other countries and global institutions have more pressing local challenges as well).

What the people want, compared to what the people will be permitted are two different entities
Hong Kong is no longer a separate entity.
The more China attempts to use authoritarian control the more people will value democracy

Extraordinary showing in the primaries along with no disruptions strong sign for the pro-democracy block, though difficulties remain.  No new candidates have been barred from running so far, this will be the critical factor to watch going forward.

My 1 for Yes is probably pollyanna.  Owing to the improved security situation in HK, any pro-democracy Legco candidate who says or even hints anything about anything will be arrested or disappeared--or in the mildest case, just disqualified.  The authorities may leave a half-dozen or so at large in order to demonstrate the Party's deep reverence for free speech and the rule of law.  (In the finest tradition of Newspeak, when they say "reverence," they will mean "contempt.") The Leader Of The Free World is rumoured to be green with envy at this arrangement.

In a departure from my usual forecast format where I begin with a base rate, with is one I’m going to start from my conclusion and work backwards. The pro-democracy movement is widely expected to win the September legislative election. I fully concur with this assessment. Local elections in November saw them gain a huge majority in district councils and there is no reason to suspect that the Security Law has done anything but bolster that support as the island city descends further in chaos. [1] The picture is far from that simple, though. The Communist Party has not and will not sit idly by why its authority is challenged. The passage of June’s National Security Law gave a group of  party officials unilateral authority to do whatever they want in the name of protecting citizens. In practice, this will allow them to make laws in any area they see fit, including elections. [2] Realizing that their usual repression playbook has failed in Hong Kong, the party will probably not move to cancel the election outright, although one can never completely discount the possibility. [3] Rather, they will use the National Security Council to legislate in their favour and short-circuit the efforts of structurally weak legislature control by pro-democracy activists. After the election, we could see the NSC move to institute primary elections which would allow them control over the candidates up for election.The mainland government also controls the Chief Executive who will undoubtedly be working closely with security officials - reducing the significance, at least in the short-term, of a pro-Western coup. [4] This in my view is the most likely scenario: pro-democracy parties win but the Party stays in control - for now. Comments welcome. UPDATE: Just wanted to add a few more thoughts to this forecast. After re-reading, I think I gave the false impression that canceling the election or allowing the protestors to win were the only options. I think this was an unintentional oversight on my part and something I might have thought about but didn’t develop that line of reasoning on paper. Of course there is a third option. The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) could suppress pro-democracy candidates prior to the election, not even giving them a chance to appear on the ballot. This is in fact already happening. The Hong Kong Free Press reports that a group of young demonstrators calling themselves the ‘local resistance camp’ fear being barred from the September election. [5] The move comes just days after ex-Hong Kong lawmaker and key democratic primary organiser Au Nok-hin was pressured by Beijing into stepping down from his role in the pro-democracy movement. [6] So it is a tactic the CCP is using but I have to question how effective it will be by September 6. They are probably hoping that by cutting off the head of the snake, they can intimidate others or put enough in jail to crush any hope of a positive outcome. But when 2 million of your 7 million people take to the streets and 3 million to the polls, it is difficult to see how this will work without major manpower. [7] Just consider this map of 2019 local elections from the New York Times to see the scale of the problem officials face. [8] Certainly there is no question that the Party could brutally crush the ongoing dissent by military means but this would require a massive escalation, one Xi Jingping seems reluctant to make at this point. Troop movements in 2017, 2018 and 2019 have failed to produce such a result despite looming terror. [9] It could happen but history casts doubt on the possibility. Clearly police crackdowns have not been enough to disperse protests and should the military roll in, that creates a whole new set of problems. I don’t think it is likely that the CCP would get away with simply faking the election results either. If they could have done that, they would have knocked all momentum out of the pro-democracy movement at the local elections in 2019 but they know they can’t do that. The best they could muster came in 2016, when they invoked their powers under the transition agreement to re-interpret decisions by the Hong Kong High Court to ban pro-democracy advocates from participating in elections. [10] The judiciary in Hong Kong is fiercely independent and is the centre of the island’s continued battle. [11] They would certainly have something to say about election meddling. [5]https://hongkongfp.com/2020/07/16/hong-kong-democrat-primaries-in-full-young-localist-resistance-camp-come-out-on-top/
[6]https://hongkongfp.com/2020/07/15/hong-kong-ex-lawmaker-withdraws-from-coordinating-democratic-primaries-after-beijings-criticism/

The silent majority has screamed “hell yes!” to pro-democracy candidates at the local level and will continue to do so in the next legislative elections. This assumes the elections are held, which if Beijing has any say, they may very well not be.

The answer to this question is assuming the results of the election  will be as announced by the Hong Kong authorities.
After the Hong Kong primaries where 600,000 voted in an election deemed illegal by the Authorities for pro-democracy candidates where a more confrontational younger group displaced older democrats, Beijing has shown its displeasure.
Candidates for the Legislative council must conform they will abide by article 6 of the new National Security Law.
Companies and individuals have reducing their digital exposure to the authorities and would appear that Beijing is gaining the upper hand.
My proposal is that Beijing wants to avoid a Tiananmen Square PR disaster and will forge ahead with the elections in September, but with hand selected candidates to ensure a victory for the mainland in its quest to amalgamate Hong Kong with China.
This will guarantee a smooth transition incorporating the new national security law where dissidents will be transported to the Mainland and a sense of stable government be established.
Pro-democracy candidates will not win a majority in Hong Kong’s Legislative Council based on the official announcement by the Hong Kong Authorities. https://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3093730/more-confrontation-looms-hong-kong-horizon  https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/04/22/asia-pacific/politics-diplomacy-asia-pacific/china-hong-kong-election/ https://www.dw.com/en/a-year-of-hong-kong-protests-is-beijing-finally-regaining-control/a-53752025  https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2020/07/17/why-now-understanding-beijings-new-assertiveness-in-hong-kong/  https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-07-13/hong-kong-protesters-cast-vote-against-security-laws/12448142
It does not fit in with the CCPs plans
CCP will force their way into power. They will try and say that a pro-CCP candidate was elected. Otherwise, they will just take over with no election.
With the addition of @KitsonJ input, I feel more confident to increase immediately.

Since the legislative council has been established there has not been a pro democracy legislative majority. Although the main pro democracy party won in 98 and 00 the total make up of the council was still pro Beijing. The polls are showing a healthy lead for pro democracy parties but the electorate only get the chance to elect 35 of the 70 members, the other 35 are "elected" by functional constituencies.  As I currently understand the question, this means winning 36 of the seats by pro democracy parties, individuals or FCs. This is very difficult given there is only the opportunity to elect 35 of them directly and although the pro Beijing parties are doing badly in polls (58% PD to 22%PB) you can reasonably expect the pro Beijing side to get 6-11 seats in the election.  I think the election being cancelled is unlikely but there would be "good" or at least excuses in place for doing so; COVID, civil unrest, the national security law.

who wants to paint a target on their back for the chinese government? not many people. there will be an 'election', but people will be reluctant to vote pro-democracy given the heavy hand china has used to deal w/ things so far. In addition, covid is being used to prevent gatherings and this should dampen momentum for protests.

Considerations: 
- 610k have turned out for an unsanctioned vote. 
- Population is just under 7.5m. 
- Approximately 1m people have openly marched since 2019.
- Voting age available  If the HK people thought there was any chance of this being a fair vote, they know they mark their own card (pun intended). So will likely just not vote. Seems to me that the majority of HK (the people with too much to lose) will not go against China. Therefore, likely the vote happens and that there will be a purge of high-profile protesters (<cough> Benny Tai </cough>) in the coming weeks to warn that (approx. = unsubstantiated guess) 20-40% who would open themselves up. Will of course update as the arrests start piling up. The Rubicon is not in the rear-view mirror any longer. https://amp.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/14/hong-kong-primaries-china-declares-pro-democracy-polls-illegal

Believe the election will take place, would be seen as weak by PBC if it didn't. Is not a guarantee that elections will not be free or fair as previously have been - yet Chinese confidence evolved rapidly what makes exhaustive influencing efforts likely.
China will appear to hold elections but they may not be fair and democratic
The polls are looking like activists are winning but I think with the new security law in place China will postpone the election
More will be learned in August. For now things are just getting started.

I am certain the election will  be held as scheduled.  For whatever reason covid19 is under control.  I am unsure of Beijing's desire to manage the results.  Letting the election run without Beijing management would most likely result in the Pro Democracy party gaining the majority. So this would let Beijinb signal to the world that the security law would not interfere with Hong Kong's self-governance. But it's the security law that the world is angry about because that represents infringement on self-governance. 
Reasons Beijing manages the results to prevent a pro-democracy majority 1)Trump may not be President in 2021 so consolidate while it can 2)already signaled a heavy hand with the security law 3)arrested persons under the security law 4) By awarding seats to loyalists the Party passes out favors. 
So since the security law is not going to be repealed there's nothing gained by signaling free elections equals self-governance. So I am more than 50 50 on the yes no split but not 100% certain.
